B982BDF1DFF8483C8AD9E9F009A9C0EB.description:
Explain why the properties of a material make it suitable for a

41A5DFD821194B139A1863A5CFAB2D34.description:

carbohydrates in aqueous solution, using yeast to provide

reactions because their molecules contain the same functional

Recall the formulae of molecules of the alcohols, methanol,

Calculate the energy change in a reaction given the

80FA4AB8574340B88573331750D7BF5B.description:
endothermic if less heat energy is released in forming bonds
in the products than is required in breaking bonds in the
reactants

FF8AD806C6574861925C21572CDF7FA5.description:
exothermic if more heat energy is released in forming bonds
in the products than is required in breaking bonds in the
reactants

energy is given out

6101A4A373A242C9A2C67D85C09C3571.description:

Describe that a life-cycle assessment for a product involves
consideration of the effect on the environment of obtaining the
raw materials, manufacturing the product, using the product
and disposing of the product when it is no longer useful

B1161BB0F41640DBBAE0645B537A1CBE.description:
Evaluate the advantages of recycling metals, including
economic implications and how recycling can preserve both the
environment and the supply of valuable raw materials

51F36AD280614B4E9CFA14C911017954.description:
Explain how a metal’s relative resistance to oxidation is related
to its position in the reactivity series

398016F4743040E58D82528C688B497E.description:
Evaluate alternative biological methods of metal
extraction (bacterial and phytoextraction) [H]

C8F9E9A6A49E412CB109C6ADFC464C27.description:
Explain why the method used to extract a metal from its ore is
related to its position in the reactivity series and the cost of the
extraction process, illustrated by: (knowledge of blast furnace is not required)

043B33AA12EB40EFB897CD82CC857186.description: Recall that the extraction of metals involves reduction of ores

E04D49015AA74BA6A01D0148535F9D70.description:
Explain oxidation as the gain of oxygen and reduction as the
loss of oxygen

B7436FE7D1314FB283F5D896795D5DDB.description:
unreactive metals are found in the Earth’s crust as the
uncombined elements

377D1B742652461F9B3BA6BE1841CB50.description:
most metals are extracted from ores found in the Earth’s
crust

E54AF7B35CA541E990C1C55C59B08772.description:
Explain the reactivity series of metals (potassium, sodium,
calcium, magnesium, aluminium, (carbon), zinc, iron,
(hydrogen), copper, silver, gold) in terms of the reactivity of
the metals with water and dilute acids and that these reactions
show the relative tendency of metal atoms to form cations

E27DB6297645417CBC4BFCB75A89EC0A.description:
Explain displacement reactions as redox reactions, in
terms of gain or loss of electrons [H]

4820C63CA12846878D6EE246223FA156.description:
Deduce the relative reactivity of some metals, by their reactions
with water, acids and salt solutions

B4AB7A6CC9CB459A87E27B7305CD2A06.description:
Core Practical: Investigate the electrolysis of copper sulfate
solution with inert electrodes and copper electrodes

796DE78F4304492FB5D5A003B9D95694.description:
Explain the formation of the products in the electrolysis of
copper sulfate solution, using copper electrodes, and how this
electrolysis can be used to purify copper

E7899D186E384725A63602C40675EB76.description:
Recall that reduction occurs at the cathode and that
oxidation occurs at the anode in electrolysis reactions [H]

28F3D7DADD4D47978C7B3776A5FC8193.description:
Explain oxidation and reduction in terms of loss or gain
of electrons [H]

5973B20B565346C5BBE0D1B18C1EFF4A.description:
Write half equations for reactions occurring at the anode
and cathode in electrolysis [H]

28915718DF6842539CE56200298F581C.description:
Predict the products of electrolysis of other binary, ionic
compounds in the molten state

650673C6D33C40FFB3D22C1DAC3CB500.description:
Explain the formation of the products in the electrolysis, using
inert electrodes, of some electrolytes, including:

24A295F34E574C22B1E094DF6298D3B9.description:
negatively charged anions migrate to the positively charged
anode

8AF4A636EEDC4C838CC078F7A315733B.description:
positively charged cations migrate to the negatively charged
cathode

A35367DA938F487191881C6F1075555C.description: Explain the movement of ions during electrolysis, in which:

035834C696114224B1672397977DEED5.description:
Describe electrolysis as a process in which electrical energy,
from a direct current supply, decomposes electrolytes

3D1E22A41FAF414691BD3D579BD7927A.description:
Recall that electrolytes are ionic compounds in the molten state
or dissolved in water

D8965C1465BA4116A6393AB13B7E180C.description:
Describe the method used to prepare a pure, dry sample of an
insoluble salt

61C1F46CE46A4EBC90D8687C6330D807.description:
Predict, using solubility rules, whether or not a precipitate will
be formed when named solutions are mixed together, naming
the precipitate if any

A3BBF3A9BD6344F18F7BC4A0EF00199F.description:
common carbonates and hydroxides are insoluble except
those of sodium, potassium and ammonium

22754B531EDA4DD1A78E2050A8AB397B.description:
common sulfates are soluble except those of lead, barium
and calcium

B07CB254999944C790C4782B1157058B.description: common chlorides are soluble except those of silver and lead

1BC529C7CDB24027A5B3FFFF8218FADD.description:
all common sodium, potassium and ammonium salts are
soluble

192A1C1A4C5748D494364904144C334D.description:
Recall the general rules which describe the solubility of common
types of substances in water:

6F34FD913929457F8737CE5DEB9E049E.description:
Describe how to carry out an acid-alkali titration, using burette,
pipette and a suitable indicator, to prepare a pure, dry salt

3BEEB0FAEBE84C26B7966D289D89A255.description:
Core Practical: Investigate the preparation of pure, dry
hydrated copper sulfate crystals starting from copper oxide
including the use of a water bath

930C0233FA9D4AE681A92D41EEC95227.description: the solution remaining, after reaction, is only salt and water

D20B8F3CD65D4315B53D4147687977EF.description:
the acid and the soluble reactant are then mixed in the
correct proportions

CB242BC856C94C6E9966FFB51DBC5F3B.description: the solution remaining is only salt and water

4FA3B6CCA9D54D00986F85AEF574C28F.description: excess of the reactant is added

BBA0F5007C4446E3968E8A70C2A68348.description:
Explain why, if soluble salts are prepared from an acid and an
insoluble reactant:

BE5657F3CCA945359F7055B8623F14CB.description:
Explain an acid-alkali neutralisation as a reaction in which
hydrogen ions (H+) from the acid react with hydroxide ions
(OH–) from the alkali to form water

9ED870CEDA444DACA430D40968AA0B5B.description:
Describe a neutralisation reaction as a reaction between an acid
and a base

47EECDBB89644A9EAF0D82E687A6E0D9.description: Explain the general reactions of aqueous solutions of acids with the following to produce salts:

63F03C00C2AB45EB99F83A70D5C1368C.description: Recall that alkalis are soluble bases

6C4EAF6239694E7B90104ADE1ACE8DC5.description:
Recall that a base is any substance that reacts with an acid to
form a salt and water only

20F51A6ECAEA493E9C07CCF925F529FD.description:
Explain the terms weak and strong acids, with respect to
the degree of dissociation into ions [H]

9B06A31063AB43D9A12CA3E0330D882E.description:
Explain the terms dilute and concentrated, with respect
to amount of substances in solution [H]

0FFF6FCA671744B3BCE57345A2B13F70.description:
Core Practical: Investigate the change in pH on adding
powdered calcium hydroxide or calcium oxide to a fixed volume
of dilute hydrochloric acid

45A5FC69EF034F8D885C16AD05E354C4.description:
Recall that as hydrogen ion concentration in a solution
increases by a factor of 10, the pH of the solution
decreases by 1 [H]

CDF332AAA7F04804B5CEFE279D4564BC.description:
Recall that the higher the concentration of hydrogen ions
in an acidic solution, the lower the pH; and the higher the
concentration of hydroxide ions in an alkaline solution,
the higher the pH [H]

36F739A3DDC349BAB980EF2DC4F6917B.description:
Recall the effect of acids and alkalis on indicators, including
litmus, methyl orange and phenolphthalein

0C9EDAB6A7674C75AA5498903348981B.description:
Recall that a neutral solution has a pH of 7 and that acidic
solutions have lower pH values and alkaline solutions higher pH
values

4E78750B24D94927AA912C80B60D0FAE.description:
Recall that acids in solution are sources of hydrogen ions and
alkalis in solution are sources of hydroxide ions

AA16717D26174579A1AC257F148FEF72.description: water used in analysis must not contain any dissolved salts

88E10E07662F4407947B5A39265CE5F5.description: sea water can be made potable by using distillation

8F065F76329F4C2EB4E1681BC37F8140.description: waste and ground water can be made potable, including the need for sedimentation, filtration and chlorination

A11FC4FE9E1E456BAC905DCCEABE2DAE.description:
Core Practical: Investigate the composition of inks using simple
distillation and paper chromatography

F6D48608A23643208253AD84446FE2C3.description: to identify substances by calculation and use of Rf values

099481B1EBC64E4B8B7E35820E5B5F1D.description: to identify substances by comparison with known substances

3E1A739F598E411C90B550932026D61E.description: to distinguish between pure and impure substances

7E8E093CE2B74253B206F1287E865056.description:
Describe paper chromatography as the separation of mixtures
of soluble substances by running a solvent (mobile phase)
through the mixture on the paper (the paper contains the
stationary phase), which causes the substances to move at
different rates over the paper

A883B7D483CD43AEA9EBE92357FF8AA3.description:
Describe an appropriate experimental technique to separate a
mixture, knowing the properties of the components of the
mixture

ABBEF4443A874A4EAED434757E0D7AF2.description:
Explain the types of mixtures that can be separated by using
the following experimental techniques:

412DD181899542B58CE8603E7F46C648.description:

substances which have a sharp melting point and mixtures
which melt over a range of temperatures

02C6A43DA64948E8B1E6772BDF5ACF15.description:
Explain the difference between the use of ‘pure’ in chemistry
compared with its everyday use and the differences in
chemistry between a pure substance and a mixture

28908C2EC93F4E6ABA084C3C8631C01A.description:
Predict the physical state of a substance under specified
conditions, given suitable data

BE1BE564BAEA40ABBA16E4A086779C94.description:
Explain the changes in arrangement, movement and energy of
particles during these interconversions

D30D7793DB1E4862BD5A973F761B25BF.description:
Recall the names used for the interconversions between the

changes: contrasted with chemical reactions that result in
chemical changes

D75ED2FF71E2435E9F67733DC8B68811.description:
Describe the arrangement, movement and the relative energy

and gas

71C71489024C4021B569D13240CE38A6.description: Topic 2 – States of matter and mixtures

785F58CD81FF4D5C9AD5240832D13222.description:

E660C71FE5F24520A08DAC2C7997A14C.description:
Explain why, in a reaction, the mass of product formed is

excess

55E5CCFFC255409686B3236E62ADCC33.description:
particles of a substance in a given mass of that
substance and vice versa [H]

B1A800F4F6644A53957B44B6864CA785.description:
particles of a substance in a given number of moles of

A7E2A1D5DD7549E881270FA70394FDF2.description:

C5209A7188A646708A4FB88D3E07164F.description:
the Avogadro constant number of particles

02980F2A94F44805BF806F3710AECF9F.description:
Recall that one mole of particles of a substance is defined
as:

46A7B4C4CD5B4DC0AF665A463FFD540E.description:
a closed system including a precipitation reaction in a closed
flask

5F275AA2D48E4ACC978B98F9EAA5C944.description:
the molecular formula of a compound from its empirical

6EBEF7A83F6849608A2202361AEFC02C.description:
the empirical formula of a compound from the formula of its
molecule

C975A767799741B898F2EAFE0D3A8BE6.description:
Calculate the formulae of simple compounds from reacting
masses or percentage composition and understand that these
are empirical formulae

C8D5C3FC3A6849CE8FCD77D9F013EAAD.description: Calculate relative formula mass given relative atomic masses

1137519AE41942B1AFC86A30606DCC63.description:
Describe most metals as shiny solids which have high melting
points, high density and are good conductors of electricity
whereas most non-metals have low boiling points and are poor
conductors of electricity

ECEC65860CC94888B42B9E8CABCAFAD8.description:
Describe the limitations of particular representations and
models, to include dot and cross, ball and stick models and
two- and three-dimensional representations

B569155609E34DB4A8807A2A6E08907C.description:
Explain the properties of metals, including malleability and the
ability to conduct electricity

5C5E850A5089405C9C1EF02F3862A373.description:
Describe, using poly(ethene) as the example, that simple

atoms

F1C2C4ABED7341D3835BA405A03B5A70.description:
Explain the properties of fullerenes including C60 and graphene

B67FABCD96E641ED960376D2435FEF7C.description:
Explain, in terms of structure and bonding, why graphite is used

in cutting tools

C84D981254D44D239BF7CF98E004D67A.description: Describe the structures of graphite and diamond

48C77B0133494B99982F765B509EEDB6.description:
Recall that graphite and diamond are different forms of carbon

37377118B2F4486F884040C3790F5A87.description:
low melting points and boiling points, in terms of forces

Explain the properties of typical covalent, simple molecular

B3A2C6A386CC474EB7FCD514FA057BCE.description:
whether or not they conduct electricity as solids, when
molten and in aqueous solution

AEDA81AFF1E1452CB356F5EFFFC1060F.description:
high melting points and boiling points, in terms of forces
between ions

40164EAE11194FAA8FD667EEC80EA928.description: Explain the properties of ionic compounds limited to:

Explain how the structure and bonding of these types of substances
results in different physical properties, including relative melting
point and boiling point, relative solubility in water and ability to
conduct electricity (as solids and in solution) AND why elements and compounds can be classed as:

6AE0267F1B9741E3900ED567436D3715.description:
Explain the formation of simple molecular, covalent substances,
using dot and cross diagrams, including:

6ECE9246C4134D6AB95BB36538F74816.description:
Recall the typical size (order of magnitude) of atoms and small
molecules

96B1499C0CEA4950AF2DD4F6CEF99EF8.description:
Recall that covalent bonding results in the formation of

02416D82DBB14B46BBB4FEF3DFC0A112.description:
Explain how a covalent bond is formed when a pair of electrons
is shared between two atoms

C41DBAA18FE14C39B78C6C2546CBC32F.description:
held together by strong electrostatic forces (ionic bonds)
between oppositely-charged ions

06EFECFAB7914CE38A0078938A2C95E9.description: consisting of a regular arrangement of ions

F5C4633E8E2C48FC840D381E24C95C5F.description:

55F42C71F46843FBB31D4D0D35BD7694.description:

Calculate the numbers of protons, neutrons and electrons in

4A66424564454F8093B94BC9DA34D3C3.description:
Recall that an ion is an atom or group of atoms with a positive

Explain how ionic bonds are formed by the transfer of electrons

Identify elements as metals or non-metals according to their

elements with similar properties are placed in the same

F2A7D20AA25D45E59EB30D0E82FF5DC9.description:
elements are arranged in order of increasing atomic number,
in rows called periods

964E7AF5F1A6476EB7F03FB584E0B09A.description: Describe that in the periodic table

Describe how Mendeleev used his table to predict the existence

231288E9D9B74701BFB845F5AEA0FCE2.description:

01E0C892E46E41ED8AB5C22791B1FCC0.description:

CCA0CD32275E4E2C93D13EB45F2D05F0.description:
Describe atoms of a given element as having the same number

Recall that most of the mass of an atom is concentrated in the

93DC952517A143418CCA949A1F62A92D.description:

overall size of the atom

C7C6ECB2F39F454B95D1ED2D51E883AF.description:
Explain why atoms contain equal numbers of protons and
electrons

EAC7080800BA4B4985EE134AFE94AB8B.description: Recall the relative charge and relative mass of:

Describe the structure of an atom as a nucleus containing

to inform people about safe-working precautions with these
